lines.text: And her with‑holds from me. Other more

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Suters to her, and riuals in my Loue:

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Supposing it a thing impossible,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: For those defects I haue before rehearst,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: That euer {% italic: Katherina %} wil be woo'd:

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Therefore this order hath {% italic: Baptista %} tane,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: That none shal haue accesse vnto {% italic: Bianca %},

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Til {% italic: Katherine %} the Curst, haue got a husband.

lines.speaker: Gru.
lines.text: {% italic: Katherine %} the curst,

lines.speaker: Gru.
lines.text: A title for a maide, of all titles the worst.

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Now shal my friend {% italic: Petruchio %} do me grace,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: And offer me disguis'd in sober robes,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: To old {% italic: Baptista %} as a schoole‑master

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Well seene in Musicke, to instruct {% italic: Bianca %},

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: That so I may by this deuice at least

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Haue leaue and leisure to make loue to her,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: And vnsuspected court her by her selfe.

lines.speaker: Gru.
lines.text: Heere's no knauerie. See, to beguile the olde‑

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Peace {% italic: Grumio %}, it is the riuall of my Loue.

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: {% italic: Petruchio %} stand by a while.

lines.speaker: Grumio.
lines.text: A proper stripling, and an amorous.

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: O very well, I haue perus'd the note:

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: Hearke you sir, Ile haue them verie fairely bound,

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: All bookes of Loue, see that at any hand,

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: And see you reade no other Lectures to her:

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: You vnderstand me. Ouer and beside

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: Signior {% italic: Baptistas %} liberalitie,

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: Ile mend it with a Largesse. Take your paper too,

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: And let me haue them verie wel perfum'd;

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: For she is sweeter then perfume it selfe

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: To whom they go to: what wil you reade to her.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: What ere I reade to her, Ile pleade for you,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: As for my patron, stand you so assur'd,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: As firmely as your selfe were still in place,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Yea and perhaps with more successefull words

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Then you; vnlesse you were a scholler sir.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Oh this learning, what a thing it is.

lines.speaker: Gru.
lines.text: Oh this Woodcocke, what an Asse it is.

lines.speaker: Petru.
lines.text: Peace sirra.

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: {% italic: Grumio %} mum: God saue you signior {% italic: Gremio %}.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: And you are wel met, Signior {% italic: Hortensio %}.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Trow you whither I am going ? To {% italic: Baptista Minola %},

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: I promist to enquire carefully

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: About a schoolemaster for the faire {% italic: Bianca %},

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: And by good fortune I haue lighted well

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: On this yong man: For learning and behauiour

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Fit for her turne, well read in Poetrie

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: And other bookes, good ones, I warrant ye.

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: 'Tis well: and I haue met a Gentleman

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Hath promist me to helpe one to another,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: A fine Musitian to instruct our Mistris,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: So shal I no whit be behinde in dutie

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: To faire {% italic: Bianca %}, so beloued of me.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Beloued of me, and that my deeds shal proue.

lines.speaker: Gru.
lines.text: And that his bags shal proue.

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: {% italic: Gremio %}, 'tis now no time to vent our loue,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Listen to me, and if you speake me faire,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Ile tel you newes indifferent good for either.

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Heere is a Gentleman whom by chance I met

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Vpon agreement from vs to his liking,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Will vndertake to woo curst {% italic: Katherine %},

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Yea, and to marrie her, if her dowrie please.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: So said, so done, is well:

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: {% italic: Hortensio %}, haue you told him all her faults?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: I know she is an irkesome brawling scold:

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: If that be all Masters, I heare no harme.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: No, sayst me so, friend ? What Countreyman?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Borne in {% italic: Verona %}, old {% italic: Butonios %} sonne:

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: My father dead, my fortune liues for me,

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: And I do hope, good dayes and long, to see.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Oh sir, such a life with such a wife, were strange:

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: But if you haue a stomacke, too't a Gods name,

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: You shal haue me assisting you in all.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: But will you woo this Wilde‑cat ?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Will I liue?

lines.speaker: Gru.
lines.text: Wil he woo her? I: or Ile hang her.

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Why came I hither, but to that intent?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Thinke you, a little dinne can daunt mine eares?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Haue I not in my time heard Lions rore?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Haue I not heard the sea, puft vp with windes,

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Rage like an angry Boare, chafed with sweat?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Haue I not heard great Ordnance in the field?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: And heauens Artillerie thunder in the skies?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Haue I not in a pitched battell heard

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Loud larums, neighing steeds, & trumpets clangue?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: And do you tell me of a womans tongue?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: That giues not halfe so great a blow to heare,

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: As wil a Chesse‑nut in a Farmers fire.

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Tush, tush, feare boyes with bugs.

lines.speaker: Gru.
lines.text: For he feares none.

lines.speaker: Grem.
lines.text: {% italic: Hortensio %} hearke:

lines.speaker: Grem.
lines.text: This Gentleman is happily arriu'd,

lines.speaker: Grem.
lines.text: My minde presumes for his owne good, and yours.

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: I promist we would be Contributors,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: And beare his charge of wooing what oere.

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: And so we wil, prouided that he win her.

lines.speaker: Gru.
lines.text: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Gentlemen God saue you. If I may be bold

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Tell me I beseech you, which is the readiest way

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: To the house of Signior {% italic: Baptista Minola %}?

lines.speaker: Bion.
lines.text: He that ha's the two faire daughters: ist he you

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Euen he {% italic: Biondello %}.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Hearke you sir, you meane not her to⸺

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Perhaps him and her sir, what haue you to do?

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Not her that chides sir, at any hand I pray.

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: I loue no chiders sir: {% italic: Biondello %}, let's away.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Well begun {% italic: Tranio %}.

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Sir, a word ere you go:

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Are you a sutor to the Maid you talke of, yea or no?

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: And if I be sir, is it any offence ?

lines.speaker: Gremio.
lines.text: No: if without more words you will get you

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Why sir, I pray are not the streets as free

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: For me, as for you?

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: But so is not she.

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: For what reason I beseech you.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: For this reason if you'l kno,

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: That she's the choise loue of Signior {% italic: Gremio %}.

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: That she's the chosen of signior {% italic: Hortensio %}.

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Softly my Masters: If you be Gentlemen

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Do me this right: heare me with patience.

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: {% italic: Baptista %} is a noble Gentleman,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: To whom my Father is not all vnknowne,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: And were his daughter fairer then she is,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: She may more sutors haue, and me for one.

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Faire {% italic: Ladaes %} daughter had a thousand wooers,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Then well one more may faire {% italic: Bianca %} haue;

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: And so she shall: {% italic: Lucentio %} shal make one,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Though {% italic: Paris %} came, in hope to speed alone.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: What, this Gentleman will out‑talke vs all.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Sir giue him head, I know hee'l proue a Iade.

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: {% italic: Hortensio %}, to what end are all these words?

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Sir, let me be so bold as aske you,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Did you yet euer see {% italic: Baptistas %} daughter ?

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: No sir, but heare I do that he hath two:

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: The one, as famous for a scolding tongue,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: As is the other, for beauteous modestie.

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Sir, sir, the first's for me, let her go by.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Yea, leaue that labour to great {% italic: Hercules %},

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: And let it be more then {% italic: Alcides %} twelue.

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Sir vnderstand you this of me (insooth)

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: The yongest daughter whom you hearken for,

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Her father keepes from all accesse of sutors,

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: And will not promise her to any man,

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: Vntill the elder sister first be wed.

lines.speaker: Petr.
lines.text: The yonger then is free, and not before.

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: If it be so sir, that you are the man

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: Must steed vs all, and me amongst the rest:

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: And if you breake the ice, and do this seeke,

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: Atchieue the elder: set the yonger free,

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: For our accesse, whose hap shall be to haue her,

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: Wil not so gracelesse be, to be ingrate.

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: Sir you say wel, and wel you do conceiue,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: And since you do professe to be a sutor,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: You must as we do, gratifie this Gentleman,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: To whom we all rest generally beholding.

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: Sir, I shal not be slacke, in signe whereof,

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: Please ye we may contriue this afternoone,

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: And quaffe carowses to our Mistresse health,

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: And do as aduersaries do in law,

lines.speaker: Tranio.
lines.text: Striue mightily, but eate and drinke as friends.

lines.speaker: Gru. Bion.
lines.text: Oh excellent motion: fellowes let's be gon.

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: The motions good indeed, and be it so,

lines.speaker: Hor.
lines.text: {% italic: Petruchio %}, I shal be your {% italic: Been venuto %}.

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: Good sister wrong me not, nor wrong your self,

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: To make a bondmaide and a slaue of mee,

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: That I disdaine: but for these other goods,

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: Vnbinde my hands, Ile pull them off my selfe,

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: Yea all my raiment, to my petticoate,

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: Or what you will command me, wil I do,

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: So well I know my dutie to my elders.

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Of all thy sutors heere I charge tel

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Whom thou lou'st best: see thou dissemble not.

lines.speaker: Bianca.
lines.text: Beleeue me sister, of all the men aliue,

lines.speaker: Bianca.
lines.text: I neuer yet beheld that speciall face,

lines.speaker: Bianca.
lines.text: Which I could fancie, more then any other.

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Minion thou lyest: Is't not {% italic: Hortensio %}?

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: If you affect him sister, heere I sweare

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: Ile pleade for you my selfe, but you shal haue him.

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Oh then belike you fancie riches more,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: You wil haue {% italic: Gremio %} to keepe you faire.

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: Is it for him you do enuie me so?

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: Nay then you iest, and now I wel perceiue

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: You haue but iested with me all this while:

lines.speaker: Bian.
lines.text: I prethee sister {% italic: Kate %}, vntie my hands.

lines.speaker: Ka.
lines.text: If that be iest, then all the rest was so.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Why how now Dame, whence growes this in­

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: {% italic: Bianca %} stand aside, poore gyrle she weepes:

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Go ply thy Needle, meddle not with her.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: For shame thou Hilding of a diuellish spirit,

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Why dost thou wrong her, that did nere wrong thee?

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: When did she crosse thee with a bitter word?

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Her silence flouts me, and Ile be reueng'd.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: What in my sight? {% italic: Bianca %} get thee in.

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: What will you not suffer me: Nay now I see

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: She is your treasure, she must haue a husband,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: I must dance bare‑foot on her wedding day,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: And for your loue to her, leade Apes in hell.

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Talke not to me, I will go sit and weepe,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Till I can finde occasion of reuenge.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Was euer Gentleman thus greeu'd as I?

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: But who comes heere.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Good morrow neighbour {% italic: Baptista %}.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Good morrow neighbour {% italic: Gremio: %} God saue

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: And you good sir: pray haue you not a daugh­ {% italic: Katerina %}, faire and vertuous.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: I haue a daughter sir, cal'd {% italic: Katerina %}.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: You are too blunt, go to it orderly.

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: You wrong me signior {% italic: Gremio %}, giue me leaue.

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: I am a Gentleman of {% italic: Verona %} sir,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: That hearing of her beautie, and her wit,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Her affability and bashfull modestie:

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Her wondrous qualities, and milde behauiour,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Am bold to shew my selfe a forward guest

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Within your house, to make mine eye the witnesse

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Of that report, which I so oft haue heard,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: And for an entrance to my entertainment,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: I do present you with a man of mine

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Cunning in Musicke, and the Mathematickes,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: To instruct her fully in those sciences,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Whereof I know she is not ignorant,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Accept of him, or else you do me wrong.

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: His name is {% italic: Litio %}, borne in {% italic: Mantua %}.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Y'are welcome sir, and he for your good sake.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: But for my daughter {% italic: Katerine %}, this I know,

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: She is not for your turne, the more my greefe.

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: I see you do not meane to part with her,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Or else you like not of my companie.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Mistake me not, I speake but as I finde,

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Whence are you sir? What may I call your name.

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: {% italic: Petruchio %} is my name, {% italic: Antonio's %} sonne,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: A man well knowne throughout all Italy.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: I know him well: you are welcome for his sake.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Sauing your tale {% italic: Petruchio %}, I pray let vs that are ? {% italic: Bacare %}, you are meruay­

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Oh, Pardon me signior {% italic: Gremio %}, I would faine be

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: I doubt it not sir. But you will curse

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Your wooing neighbors: this is a guift

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Very gratefull, I am sure of it, to expresse

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: The like kindnesse my selfe, that haue beene

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: More kindely beholding to you then any:

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Freely giue vnto this yong Scholler, that hath

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Beene long studying at {% italic: Rhemes %}, as cunning

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: In Greeke, Latine, and other Languages,

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: As the other in Musicke and Mathematickes:

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: His name is {% italic: Cambio %}: pray accept his seruice.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: A thousand thankes signior {% italic: Gremio %}:

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Welcome good {% italic: Cambio %}. But gentle sir,

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Me thinkes you walke like a stranger,

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: May I be so bold, to know the cause of your comming?

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Pardon me sir, the boldnesse is mine owne,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: That being a stranger in this Cittie heere,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Do make my selfe a sutor to your daughter,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Vnto {% italic: Bianca %}, faire and vertuous:

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Nor is your firme resolue vnknowne to me,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: In the preferment of the eldest sister.

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: This liberty is all that I request,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: That vpon knowledge of my Parentage,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: I may haue welcome 'mongst the rest that woo,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: And free accesse and fauour as the rest.

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: And toward the education of your daughters:

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: I heere bestow a simple instrument,

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: And this small packet of Greeke and Latine bookes:

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: If you accept them, then their worth is great:

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: {% italic: Lucentio %} is your name, of whence I pray.

lines.speaker: Tra.
lines.text: Of {% italic: Pisa %} sir, sonne to {% italic: Vincentio %}.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: A mightie man of {% italic: Pisa %} by report,

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: I know him well: you are verie welcome sir:

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Take you the Lute, and you the set of bookes,

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: You shall go see your Pupils presently.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Holla, within.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: Sirrah, leade these Gentlemen

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: To my daughters, and tell them both

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: These are their Tutors, bid them vse them well,

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: We will go walke a little in the Orchard,

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: And then to dinner: you are passing welcome,

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: And so I pray you all to thinke your selues.

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Signior {% italic: Baptista %}, my businesse asketh haste,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: And euerie day I cannot come to woo,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: You knew my father well, and in him me,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Left soli eire to all his Lands and goods,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Which I haue bettered rather then decreast,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Then tell me, if I get your daughters loue,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: What dowrie shall I haue with her to wife.

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: After my death, the one halfe of my Lands,

lines.speaker: Bap.
lines.text: And in possession twentie thousand Crownes.

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: And for that dowrie, Ile assure her of

lines.speaker: Pet.

lines.text: To watch the night in stormes, the day in cold,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Whil'st thou ly'st warme at home, secure and safe,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: And craues no other tribute at thy hands,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: But loue, faire lookes, and true obedience;

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Too little payment for so great a debt.

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Such dutie as the subiect owes the Prince,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Euen such a woman oweth to her husband:

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: And when she is froward, peeuish, sullen, sowre,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: And not obedient to his honest will,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: What is she but a foule contending Rebell,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: And gracelesse Traitor to her louing Lord?

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: I am asham'd that women are so simple,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: To offer warre, where they should kneele for peace:

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Or seeke for rule, supremacie, and sway,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: When they are bound to serue, loue, and obay.

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Why are our bodies soft, and weake, and smooth,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Vnapt to toyle and trouble in the world,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: But that our soft conditions, and our harts,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Should well agree with our externall parts ?

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Come, come, you froward and vnable wormes,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: My minde hath bin as bigge as one of yours,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: My heart as great, my reason haplie more,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: To bandie word for word, and frowne for frowne;

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: But now I see our Launces are but strawes:

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Our strength as weake, our weakenesse past compare,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: That seeming to be most, which we indeed least are.

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: Then vale your stomackes, for it is no boote,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: And place your hands below your husbands foote:

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: In token of which dutie, if he please,

lines.speaker: Kate.
lines.text: My hand is readie, may it do him ease.

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Why there's a wench: Come on, and kisse mee {% italic: Kate %}.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Well go thy waies olde Lad for thou shalt ha't.

lines.speaker: Vin.
lines.text: Tis a good hearing, when children are toward.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: But a harsh hearing, when women are froward,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: Come {% italic: Kate %}, weee'le to bed,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: We three are married, but you two are sped.

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: 'Twas I wonne the wager, though you hit the white,

lines.speaker: Pet.
lines.text: And being a winner, God giue you good night.

lines.speaker: Horten.
lines.text: Now goe thy wayes, thou hast tam'd a curst

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Tis a wonder, by your leaue, she wil be tam'd so.
